author: Zakhiggins

I've had certain partners that are easier to deal with than others with this kind of thing for sure, and being with someone who actually understands these things really helps, but at the end of the day no one wants to be with someone who's grinding 100% of the time. There's more to life than that, and whats the point of being in a relationship if you never see the other person. I also get the working in music/freelance lifestyle, and sometimes its hard to even want to do fun things outside of it when you're so focused on this thing that really excites you that also is your livelyhood.

Its such a hard thing to get right and in my experience with certain partners, its been an ongoing arguement, even in the past when i've had salary jobs and a very predictable schedule. So i'm not sure it goes away by making your life more regimented. I think the only answer here is being super open and radically honest about everything. 

In my experience, letting your partner know when you've been asked to do something before you've agreed to it, makes them feel like they're a part of the thought process behind the work and less like they're just observing you living your life from the outside. Even if you were always gonna say yes to it anyway, at least they feel like they have some control and are on the same team as you. IME you just gotta go out of your way to make them feel like they're doing it all with you. They feel closer to you in a situation where they could just as easily feel like they're being pushed away. I'm not sure what way you've went about it, thats just my experience. If you're living with your partner you kinda have to see yourselves as the same person working toward the same thing, as opposed to two individuals with their own lives.

Also going out of your way to be spontaneous and do something fun and/or stupid like you're teenagers when things arent as busy goes a long way when things are.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Tl;dr- where you are matters as much as who you are. 

I’m also from a small town, moved to LA trying to get famous and got my ass handed to me by artists who were better looking & more talented and yet were still struggling to be seen. But I kept at it because I’m tenacious, (read: delusional, as all artists must be.)

I was able to work *for* some of those artists cause I had a diverse skillset, and I was full time music after about 4 years, by the time I was 26. Doing gigs at hotels and playing guitar or recording for other people, teaching guitar, leading music at churches, all the while pouring evening last ounce of money & energy into my artist career, until my last real artist project broke up the week we were supposed to sign our first record deal. I was 36. 

That’s when I moved to Nashville and really gave myself over to music directing and producing and writing for other artists. I did it as a consolation while I regrouped to find my next thing, but for some reason, when I made the move all the sudden my whole career made sense to me. 

As it turns out, my real joy comes not from the sound of my own voice, but from helping others find theirs. When I acquiesced to that very real, very culturally counterintuitive calling, I thrived. 

All the sudden I was playing music with and for a bunch of my heroes, and all my friends who were artists starting getting famous. And (shocker) I was really glad I wasn’t one of them. 

I always thought that my calling was to help people feel less alone in the world, and that the music I made was the vehicle for that calling. In the end, it turns out it was the relationships i built through music that were the real vehicle.  

It took me a long time to figure out who I was, and the cities I was in played a huge role in that story. Nashville built its whole industry on people who want to *help* artists, not just *be* artists. 

I miss LA every day but I’m in the right place. So, my friend, where is the right place for you?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Loving your job 80% of the time is a phenomenal, compared to the general public. 

One thing I’m amazed by working with Cian & Rollmottle is their endless capacity for positivity during a project. No matter how shitty my delivery or communication, they approach things with a smile and a sense of humor. I’ve literally never heard either of them complain. I thought commiserating about shitty aspects of a gig was a part of professionalism, but they have me rethinking things. 

In my own projects, when I approach clients with patience and curiosity, I find that not only are they happier faster, I’m happier the whole time. It’s SO MUCH EASIER to say “let’s try it” than to say “here’s why that’s not a good idea.” I find I learn a lot that way too. 

In any case, going back in to fix or add only bugs me when I think I’m supposed to be done. If I can stay open, then opening a session feels a lot easier. 

So I guess my advice is: you might have fewer problem clients if you try to remember they’re not problems to solve, they’re people to serve.

author: cian riordan
content:
The take-way from all this blibber blabber is that I went in expecting to be trusted immediately. I wanted to show off… to establish ‘status’ as Ruairi put it. But it took years of patiently learning the ropes at the highest level to be trusted by the folks in the highest circles. I look back upon that now and I’m still amazed that I was paid to do that. It was essentially like a paid college degree in making records.

So now when I go into studios with a big client, I see the assistant through those eyes. I’m kind but communicative. If they can hang in the back and figure out how I work, anticipate breaks — get the menu book ready — know that we’re going to change gears — start setting up for that — then they get looped in. They get my running commentary on what techniques I’m doing. They get the inside baseball… “I wish they fired this fucking drummer”. 

I agree with Ruairi that this type of coming up through the ranks is a loss for up and comers. It was tried and true way to make people understand the ins and outs of studio technique, etiquette, professionalism. I’m glad I got to ride one of the last waves of it. I wouldn’t be here making records at this level if it weren’t for the opportunities I had at the bottom levels of the industry.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Story time. Last night me and my gf saw Janelle Monáe on her age of pleasure tour at the Ryman here in Nashville. While she was making her entrance on stage something weird happened to the sound. Loud pop, clicking, and then no signal, but seemed like the in-ears / on stage monitoring were still working. Her and the band played through the entire first song while everyone in the audience was just looking around confused. Many heads turning to the sound board. Eventually the crowd started a 'we can't hear you' chant and Janelle and the band realized what was going on. They all calmly walked off stage. Took maybe ten minutes for it all to get sorted with the sound. Then Janelle and her band proceeded to come back out redo the entire intro / first song and give maybe the greatest live performance I've ever witnessed. The show ended with a double encore. It felt like such an amazing example of class and professionalism. I got the sense that she decided, after walking off the stage the first time, that not a single person in the audience will remember this show being anything but amazing and it was. Truly undeniable. If anyone here has a chance to catch any of the remaining shows on her tour, I could not recommend it enough. 🤘

author: Slow Hand
content:
This feeling intersects with two thoughts that have been at the forefront of my mind for the last year:

1) Everyone wants to be happy, but no one wants to be satisfied with what they have.

2) What have you done to let go of your old identity so that a new one can grow?

The first is a reminder for gratitude and a mantra of sorts that tells me that I'm enough and that I have enough. To tamp down runaway desire and appreciate what is in front of me.

The second is a call to identify my inhibiting beliefs and behaviors. To strip away the aspects that are no longer helpful or that burden me. To let go.

Thinking on it now, one prevents me from being ruled by the future and the second un-tethers me from the past. 

If our goal is to become unstuck and discover a new direction we can open a lot of doors by examining our relationships with the future and the past.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Fun question! I hate to complicate an already nuanced premise at the outset, but when I observe my own choices and think of each category I see myself living both sides of all three spectrums, but in different domains:

**For example:** I could be short-term in career objectives and overt achievement and long-term oriented in relationships and satisfaction. Cutting edge in creative pursuits, but classics in my personal taste. Specialist in my mode of expression, and generalist in my interests.

The more I subdivide and examine the question the more I find exceptions to everything. I am steeped in knowledge, but I seek wisdom above most things, which some philosophies would consider contradictory.

This Anais Nin quote comes to mind:

> "We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another, unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made of layers, cells, constellations."

I think people are extremely lopsided and unbalanced when you start to drill down into their psyches, and that's wonderful! 

For the sake of refining this question and narrowing the scope, should we confine these three axis to only record making? Or do we want to approach it in a holistic sense?

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: LAPhill
content:
With any passion that becomes a career, a certain amount of the mystique is bound to wear off once you become one of the magic makers. To use your analogy, dating a new girl feels different than a year in, vs. being married, vs. having a family. It's absolutely normal for the type of love you have for music to evolve over time and repetition.

I kind of doubt that earning money from music is the root cause of your feelings. But it might be affecting how you encounter music. If it's all feeling too ordinary, then break the ordinary. Go listen to live music that's far away from anything you touch. Pick up an instrument you don't know how to play and get in a room with some friends and enjoy being bad, but exploring music like a child. 

The "quitting" thing often feels like something often born out of rough working experiences, or perhaps just too mundane. Bills have to get paid (burgers gotta get flipped) but perhaps you can balance those gigs with things that challenge and excite you, even if they're not particularly lucrative. 

tl;dr I think we all go through phases of questioning if the career is worth it, if not questioning our relationship with music itself, but in my experience, almost everyone comes out the other side after a bit of a mental reset.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Last thing on the role of humor. I had an epiphany last year with my then-girlfriend. We'd been having a reoccurring friction in our relationship where she thought that I wasn't taking things seriously enough. Not everything, mind you, but there were certain scenarios where my humor was dismaying to her.

Eventually, what we discovered by accident one evening when exploring our personal values was that we both had very different understandings about the role and purpose of humor.

To me humor is a playground for creativity, trying things out, and testing ideas. It's play. To her, humor was something that she had come to know as a defense mechanism for defusing tense situations. She was very explicit about that.

As a result of these unvoiced beliefs there were moments where I was being playful and she would interpret it as me changing the subject or downplaying something. She thought I was being defensive. This difference in beliefs was hidden to both of us and it was leading us into frustration because we thought we had the same understanding of what something was.

I'm rambling a bit at this point, but It's always a huge relief when you manage to uncover the unspoken assumptions that you or another person are holding.

I had to learn to apply this to personal relationships. Sometimes relationships (romantic and non-romantic) seem perfect on paper but when you consistently feel worse after spending time with someone it doesn’t matter if you can’t intellectualize it, they are not the people you should be around anymore. If it feels good to be around someone it is good to be around them. If it doesn’t feel good them it’s not good to be around them. Simple as that - stop trying to overthink it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, it's hard to say what's best without a more holistic understanding of who you are and your circumstances, so I’m reluctant to offer any hard suggestions. Making a career in the music industry is what engineers would call a "wicked" problem. It's not something that has a repeatable solution, and what works for someone rarely works the same way for the next person.

That said, I see that you’re from Boston. I lived there for seven years, and the talent pool in that city is tremendous. I think if you found yourself back home in Boston it would be a worthwhile investment to integrate yourself into the scene of young musicians that are centered around the schools in the Back Bay like Berklee, NEC, and Boston Conservatory. There are some immensely talented, diverse, and creative people from all around the world based at those institutions and they all exist within 8 blocks of each other. It’s rare to have such a concentration of driven musicians all mingling amongst each other. This is a massive resource that you can tap into. They're *all* trying to make something great and explore what's possible.

It's a unique opportunity to discover collaborators, build relationships, earn experience in your craft, and build strong connections for the future as you grow alongside these people. On top of that, Boston has numerous recording studios where you can intern and assist. There’s a lot of experience to be gained working in a studio that simply won’t be taught to you in a recording program. Supplement that practical experience with hard work, and some book learning and you can do very well for yourself.

There’s more that I’m not touching-on, but I think if you ended up back in Boston it not be as much as a trade-off as you may think.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Going to rep Tailscale here.

Been investing in some infrastructure and future planning over here. The problem I was trying to solve was making my working drive available to me for when I’m away from my studio so I can continue to be responsive to clients at all times. 

Tailscale allows you to create a secure, private VPN without having to have a networking PHD and compromising your network. Basically install the client on a device, 2-factor auth into the client and any other client you have installed on any device signed in with those same credentials are available to you as if you’re on the same local network, even if you’re on another network anywhere else in the world. It’s an actual game changer.

For a variety of reasons including keeping my mastering rig lean and clean and because the rig is not always on because I don’t want to run my HVAC 24/7, I sync a clone of my working drive from my mastering rig to a drive attached to an always-on Mac in my home network that has the Tailscale client authenticated. I’ve got screen share enabled on that Mac and now from any other device, I can sign into it and grab whatever I need from that clone drive. You can install the client on virtually any device including NAS’s and mobile phones so it opens up whole new avenues in how to think about availability of your data, traveling, 3rd party cloud vs. rolling your own, etc. Tons of possibilities. Really big fan. Love the future.

some artist I work with will literally dream up the whole production and I'm kind of facilitating and bringing it into the real world. others will come with loose ideas and others will show up with absolutely nothing and go off the feeling in the moment. some are more involved than others in the production

your relationship with them is probably the biggest factor in knowing how far you can push their creatively bounderies.

author: ALXCPH
content:
at your level i wouldnt worry about singing teachers. What i would worry about is connecting your vocal chords to your ears and brain. technique and breathing isn't something to worry about just yet. A teacher/mentor can be great for guidance. But they can be expensive. A few lessons could def put you in a direction. I would start with ear training learning to hear melodies. Usually when people are unable to hit a note it has less to do with technique and more to do with their ability to decern pitch and notes. 

Starting out is always tough, but start by singing everyday, sing along to your favourite songs. also try and pull up a piano and press a key and then sing the note, then press another key and sing that note, this will teach you to actively target notes with your voice/ears. Learn to sing simple songs on your own without any backing tracks or music. Nursery rhymes are great, they are simple and a lot of people have them internalised. When you get some more confidance, try and have a static chord or note, and sing different notes on top of it and see how the different notes feel / sound and really internalise that.

author: cian riordan
content: Insight gives you A LOT of visual information that isn't really useful unless you know what you're looking for. I have two visual meters while I mix... a janky old Goldline RTA analyzer and a TC Electronics Clarity. The RTA is useful for quick visual cues of kick to snare balance, how subby something really is, or when I'm working out phase relationships between drum mics... I can quickly glance to help aid with decision making. It's not necessary for me to mix, but I've had it for 15 years and it helps me make certain technical decisions quicker. The Clarity is very useful for the loudness radar. I basically set a guide LUFS (in my case, I'm usually shooting for -9) and you get a great visual representation of where you're at over the course of the song. Its especially useful to avoid fader creep... where I might nail the dynamics and loudness in the earlier parts of the song, but might overlook the last chorus being significantly louder, and in some cases, more squashed than it needs to be. I'm also an LCR panning guy, and it has a 'balance-o-meter' feature that has a cool weighted algorithm for determining if your mix is leaning left or right.

content:
I loved the analysis, I had thoughts about a few points he mentioned. 

1. Paradox of climbing up to the highest level
Could Michael Jordan have become Michael Jordan if it wasn’t for the feeling of someone chasing behind him to become one of the greatest of all time? There is only one Michael Jordan, and can anyone else be that one and only without going through what he has put himself through? 

2. Acceptance vs Dissatisfaction
I think the dilemma here is between satisfaction and acceptance vs beating. I don’t think one or the other is necessarily the answer, but I think a good place to be is finding acceptance in where I am right now while still beating on myself to keep on improving to the highest level I could be. 

3. Potential
This is a crazy concept to me. Who is anyone to evaluate someone’s ceiling of improvement? Spider defined the meaning of ‘potential’ perfectly in my opinion. Not his exact works but; one’s capable/willing range of adaptation. Did the professor in Whiplash really expand his students’ potential in this sense? 

4. Abusive Internal voice 
I love how he saw the professor as our internal voice. And it made perfect sense to why I was so obsessed with this movie and the character. He was myself to me all along. I went back and forth over and over on whether this relationship was worth it to either of them. I think perhaps limited to this particular two people, because they had common goals/interests and made it happen. 

5. Joy?
I feel that this is the most simple and complex out of all things here. Can anyone NOT experience any frustration while trying to get better at something? If the answer is no, is there a way to better manage the frustration? 

Pursuit vs Result, our brain works the most consistently when we look towards pursuit. Result feels good but not for long, but what if the result meant more than just the goal being achieved? What if the “result” portion leads to another pursuit after another?
